info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued August 20 at 4:54PM AST by NWS San Juan
info.description: ...There is an increased risk of flooding across Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands through midweek... Showers and thunderstorms associated with the Tropical Storm Franklin...now located over the eastern Caribbean and well south of the local islands...will continue to spread across Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands through the middle of the workweek. Rainbands, with scattered to numerous showers and isolated thunderstorms, reached the U.S. Virgin Islands and eastern Puerto Rico this morning, and have spread across the rest of Puerto Rico in the afternoon. The potential for showers and thunderstorms will continue tonight and Tuesday. The resulting rains will increase the risk for urban and small stream flooding as well as flash flooding, which could also lead to mudslides and rapid river rises. Based on the most recent guidance, the most likely period for scattered to widespread rains will continue through Tuesday morning, with the areas most likely to receive the highest rainfall accumulations across eastern and southern sections of Puerto Rico. In these areas, there is the potential for rainfall totals to reach 2-4 inches with isolated higher amounts. Elsewhere across Puerto Rico and across the U.S. Virgin Islands, rainfall totals of 1-3 inches with isolated higher amounts are possible. This product will be updated as needed. Please, continue to monitor the progress of this feature, which based on the most recent tropical weather outlook, has a high formation chance within the next 2-7 days.
